Thus after the proper manner, one should rather
Employ the arm of the higher shoulder for this,
To avoid an ungraceful pose.

22. And further, to sustain a proper appearance,
there is another matter worthy of concern
by bold minds, who notice everything,
to wit: figures which are not in action
should not raise both hands or arms
at the same time; it is good to recognize
that variation offers delight.
One should also avoid this with the legs and feet.
One should not have both arms or legs performing the same action, unless the action of the figure requires it.

23. Further, it seems that cannot stop
and rest their spirits, as they work,
without allowing (with permission) breasts and buttocks
to be seen at the same time; it seems such people
want to be in the park with the theatrical players
who consider unnatural things such as
jumping and tumbling as art;
but painters should be on guard against this.
left-middleOne must not be too extreme, twisting a figure out of proportion.

24. Yes, ordinary folk speak ill of those
who hope to embellish their work in this way,
concocting impossible things:
distorted, twisted, the limbs broken,
what the Italians call stropiato.
There are more examples of this to be wary of,
Such as the hand twisted and forced onto the arm,
And the foot wrenched contrary to the knee.
left-middleOne should not distort the limbs of a figure too much.1 note: Miedema 455: a common complaint about 16th c. Italian art, which, via VM, ended up as a complaint about some Dutch stuff too.

25. Thus one must keep to moderation
in turning and bending, according to real life:
in a face upturned in distress,
do not let the head hang back
too far to allow the eyes to point
directly toward heaven; and then
in a figure stooping low, do not allow
the shoulders to reach the navel.
left-middleOn turning the head away from the direction of the body

26. One should also not turn the head further
that when the chin is directly over the armpit;
though arms and legs are somewhat freer,
as we observe, raising either hand so high
that the elbows are higher than
the armpits, is nothing to praise.
These rules and others like them
Nature upholds with an affirming seal.
left-middleSacred figures do not need much turning of the head.

27. A person lifting up a weight,
as our experience teaches us every day,
will easily place one foot forward
to establish a support for the body,
